text: Dagestan profile Published duration 17 January 2018 The Russian Republic of Dagestan, which translates as"land of the mountains", is situated in Russia's turbulent North Caucasus with Chechnya and Georgia to the west, Azerbaijan to the south and the Caspian Sea to the east. So high are its peaks in some places that certain areas are accessible only by helicopter. The republic is also famed for its ethnic and linguistic diversity, being home to more than 30 languages. Several dozen Muslim peoples have settled among the high valleys over the centuries. image copyright AFP image caption Villages cling to steep hillsides in Dagestan's spectacular mountainous interior The Avars form the largest ethnic group and account for about a fifth of the population. A further substantial proportion is made up of Dargins, Kumyks and Lezgins. About 10 per cent are ethnic Russians. There are also Laks, Tabasarans and Nogai, to name but a few of the other significant groups. The <role id='role-0-Participant'trigno='0'><role id='role-0-Participant'trigno='0'>republic</role></role>'s constitution <trigger id='trigger-0'>declares</trigger> the protection of the interests of all of Dagestan's peoples to be a fundamental principle. It is a delicate balance to maintain, in what is Russia's most ethnically diverse province. The republic has oil and gas reserves and also the fisheries potential offered by a share in the resources of the Caspian sea. However, it is prey to organized <trigger id='trigger-1'>crime</trigger> and regional instability. The crime barons may prosper but the people are amongst the poorest in Russia. History Dagestan was the birth place of Imam Shamil, the legendary fighter who in the 19th century spearheaded fierce <trigger id='trigger-2'>resistance</trigger> by <role id='role-2-Impeder'trigno='2'>tribesmen</role> of Chechnya and Dagestan to the spread of the Russian empire. His name is still revered by many in both republics. image copyright AFP image caption Federal <role id='role-3-Impeder'trigno='3'>troops</role> were deployed to <trigger id='trigger-3'>repel</trigger> incursions by Chechen militants in the 1990s When the Bolsheviks sought to enforce control in the Caucasus in the early 1920s, Dagestan became an autonomous Soviet republic within the Russian Federation. During the Stalinist period, its <role id='role-19-PassengerArtifact'trigno='19'>peoples</role> <trigger id='trigger-19'>escaped</trigger> the mass deportation inflicted on their Chechen neighbours and many others. After the fall of the Soviet Union, the republic's authorities stayed loyal to Russia, but the region became infamous for its lawlessness and corruption. Organised <trigger id='trigger-4'>crime</trigger> is reported to flourish and kidnappings and violence are commonplace. <trigger id='trigger-5'>Firearms</trigger> are ubiquitous and <trigger id='trigger-6'>assassinations</trigger> are a regular event. <role id='role-7-Participant'trigno='7'><role id='role-7-Participant'trigno='7'>Moscow</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>blames</trigger> much of this on Chechen-based separatism, but <role id='role-8-Participant'trigno='8'><role id='role-8-Participant'trigno='8'>others</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>say</trigger> lust for profit, combined with a gun culture, is the root <role id='role-8-Topic'trigno='8'>cause</role>. Budennovsk and beyond In the 1990s, separatist warlords from neighbouring Chechen openly led armed operations in Dagestan on several occasions. In 1995 and 1996, <role id='role-9-Jailer'trigno='9'>they</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>seized</trigger> hundreds of <role id='role-9-Detainee'trigno='9'>hostages</role> in hospitals in the Dagestani <role id='role-9-Place'trigno='9'>towns</role> of Budennovsk and Kizlyar. <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>Scores</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>died</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-11'>attacks</trigger>. image copyright AFP image caption Dagestan sees frequent <trigger id='trigger-12'>attacks</trigger> on security <role id='role-12-Target'trigno='12'>forces</role> and <trigger id='trigger-13'>assassinations</trigger> Dagestan's Muslims, who tend to follow sufism combined with local tradition, generally steered clear of Chechen-style separatism, but after the late 1990s, radical and militant elements said to be linked with the more fundamentalist wahhabist tendency began to gain in influence. In August 1999, an Islamic <role id='role-15-Communicator'trigno='15'><role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'><role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'>body</role></role></role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>declared</trigger> an independent state in parts of Dagestan and Chechnya, and <trigger id='trigger-15'>called</trigger> on <role id='role-15-Recipient'trigno='15'>Muslims</role> to take up arms against Russia in a holy war. Chechen <role id='role-16-Transporter'trigno='16'>fighters</role> <trigger id='trigger-16'>crossed</trigger> into <role id='role-16-Destination'trigno='16'>Dagestan</role> in support, but within a few weeks, Russian <role id='role-17-Impeder'trigno='17'>forces</role> had <trigger id='trigger-17'>suppressed</trigger> the insurrection. The republic has seen numerous <trigger id='trigger-18'>bombings</trigger> targeted at the Russian <role id='role-18-Target'trigno='18'>military</role> stationed in the <role id='role-18-Place'trigno='18'>republic</role>.

text: British Security Services Questioned About Surveillance Priorities LONDON — For the second time in a month Britain’s security services are facing awkward questions about their surveillance policies, after it emerged the ringleader of Saturday’s terror <trigger id='trigger-0'>attack</trigger> in the heart of London was known to them and had been interrogated in the past. The British-Pakistani, who police are not naming for operational reasons, was also a recognized Islamic State follower in the streets around his home in the east London district of Barking, where he tried to recruit children and proselytized openly in a nearby park, sparking a complaint to the police by a local resident. The 27-year-old, father of at least two young children, appeared also in a television documentary last year in which he was pictured unfurling an Islamic State banner and later arguing with police during a London protest organized by radical preacher Anjem Choudary, a convicted IS recruiter. Last month, community and mosque leaders in Manchester and neighbors of Salman Abedi, the British-Libyan who carried out the May 22 concert <trigger id='trigger-1'>bombing</trigger> in the city, accused the security services of missing several opportunities to <trigger id='trigger-2'>identify</trigger> him as a high-risk militant. FILE-A police officer stands outside Didsbury mosque in Manchester, Britain, May 24, 2017. At least five times locals warned the police of their fears about the 22-year-old suicide bomber. One community worker said he contacted authorities after Abedi said being a suicide bomber was OK. Insufficient response Neither Britain’s domestic intelligence service MI5 nor the Manchester police responded to the claims, but lawmakers have demanded to know why Abedi was seen just as a peripheral figure and one not requiring surveillance and investigation. FILE-Salman Abedi, the bomber behind the Manchester suicide <trigger id='trigger-3'>bombing</trigger>, is seen in this image taken from CCTV on the night he committed the <trigger id='trigger-4'>attack</trigger> in this handout photo released, May 27, 2017, from the Greater Manchester Police. Similar questions are being prompted again in the wake of the van-and-knife <trigger id='trigger-5'>attack</trigger> in the London Bridge district of Britain’s capital. Erica Gasparri, a mother of three who lived in Barking told local media she had reported Abedi two years ago, after he approached kids in a local park. She says she confronted him after her two children came home and said, “Mummy I want to become a Muslim.” The parents of the ringleader of Saturday’s <trigger id='trigger-6'>attack</trigger> are reported to have been asylum seekers from Pakistan. According to local media, the man, nicknamed Abz, worked at various times for a fast-food outlet, a clothing store and subsequently for the London Underground system. FILE-Police attend to an incident on London Bridge in London, Britain, June 3, 2017. A onetime friend of the ringleader also told the BBC that he warned police, alerting them to comments made about previous terrorist <trigger id='trigger-7'>attacks</trigger> in Britain and of his alarm at the man's increasingly extremist beliefs. The friend said the alleged attacker was a keen follower of American radical preacher Ahmad Musa Jibril and would watch YouTube videos of the cleric. “He used to listen to a lot of Musa Jibril,” he told the BBC. “I phoned the anti-terror hotline. I spoke to the gentleman. I told him about our conversation and why I think he was radicalized. . . I did my bit, I know a lot of other people did their bit, but the authorities did not do their bit,” he added. Security strategy review A senior Conservative official told VOA that there is deep frustration in Downing Street about Saturday’s attack and the fact that at least one of the assailants was known to the authorities. Prime Minister Theresa May promised to review Britain’s counter-terrorism strategy, holding out the prospects of enhanced powers for the security services and longer jail sentences for extremists. She said she wants to take a tougher line with internet providers and social media businesses that allow extremist material on their sites. Police and counter-terror officers launched further raids early Monday in east London. A police spokesman said “a number” of people had been <trigger id='trigger-9'>detained</trigger>. Local residents reported hearing bangs and gunshots during the raids. On Sunday, police <trigger id='trigger-10'>arrested</trigger> 12 people, seven women and five men in connection with Saturday’s terror attack. One of the men has since been <trigger id='trigger-11'>released</trigger> from custody.

text: Unmanned aircraft primed specifically to chase and catch weaponised consumer drones will be taken for a spin in the coming months. Anti-drone unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are to be taken for counter-terrorist test flights on a UK military base, E & T has learned. It is understood they will be flown in exercises designed to simulate a real-life pursuit of a terrorist drone. Police and the military are believed to be concerned about the prospect of <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>terrorists</role> modifying small, off-the-shelf <role id='role-0-Instrument'trigno='0'>drones</role> to launch <trigger id='trigger-0'>attacks</trigger> on British <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>soil</role>. Capturing drones using swarms of net-casting UAVs working in tandem is one of several options being considered by defence chiefs. Developing radio frequency denial systems to create a forcefield-type wall around government sensitive areas could also form part of the longer-term strategy. British engineering firm OpenWorks already manufactures the SkyWall 100, an anti-drone bazooka which launches a net at flying objects and parachutes them to the ground. However, James Rogers, an expert in drone warfare who is associate lecturer at the University of York, predicted “non-kinetic options” would ultimately prove more effective than “blunt force” tactics. “There are loads of different ways to <trigger id='trigger-1'>bring down</trigger> a <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>drone</role>,” he said. “It’s now about finding what is the most effective way to do it. If <role id='role-2-Attacker'trigno='2'>you</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>shoot</trigger> <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>it</role> down, well, what if it’s rigged as an improvised explosive device?” On being told about the upcoming test flight event, he said: “There is a big debate out there at the moment about what the best way is to <trigger id='trigger-3'>counter</trigger> these small <role id='role-3-Target'trigno='3'>drones</role>, whether they are used by hobbyists causing a bit of a nuisance or in a more sinister manner by a terrorist actor.” The ISIL terror group has already used basic, easy-to-buy drones to carry out reconnaissance and drop bombs in the region of Mosul, where the Iraqi government is retaking territory from the self-styled caliphate. US security services reportedly believe commercially available <role id='role-4-Vehicle'trigno='4'>UAVs</role> could in future be used by <role id='role-4-Transporter'trigno='4'>terrorists</role> more widely to <trigger id='trigger-4'>carry</trigger> hazardous chemicals, radioactive material or <role id='role-4-PassengerArtifact'trigno='4'>grenades</role> in Western <role id='role-4-Destination'trigno='4'>cities</role>. Rogers told E & T: “We talk about precision warfare with regards to American drone warfare. This is kind of the other side of it. These are precision missiles. You can hone in on your exact target. Proliferation of these precision technologies is what this is.” Forcing drone manufacturers to programme their machines so that they have pre-set areas within their positioning systems which they are barred from entering could be part of the answer to the conundrum, Rogers said, although he added: “You can always override that, so it’s a hard one.” In the UK there are said to have been dozens of sightings in recent months of drones flying over sites deemed to be part of the country’s critical infrastructure. It is not known if these were being flown by people harbouring harmful intent or just curious hobbyists. One well-placed source said he believed there had been thousands of such incidents recorded so far. Enthusiasts who flew drones over military sites were “just morons” , he added. A British air safety watchdog yesterday revealed how an RAF Chinook helicopter at an airbase in Hampshire was nearly downed after <role id='role-5-Instrument'trigno='5'>it</role> came within 130ft of <trigger id='trigger-5'>colliding</trigger> with a <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'>drone</role>. The person controlling the drone was never tracked down. All agencies with responsibility for responding to emergencies are now factoring drones into their war games, according to Dave Sloggett, who runs exercises for the police, military and others. “For the last nine months, every single exercise I’ve done for the emergency services has had a drone element in there somewhere,” said Sloggett, who has also authored a book on drone warfare. <role id='role-6-Transporter'trigno='6'>Criminals</role> have been known to use <role id='role-6-Vehicle'trigno='6'>drones</role> to <trigger id='trigger-6'>carry</trigger> drugs and mobile <role id='role-6-PassengerArtifact'trigno='6'>phones</role> into <role id='role-6-Destination'trigno='6'>prisons</role>, over borders and even across the Straits of Gibraltar from Africa to Europe. Dutch and French police have reportedly trained several different species of eagle to catch drones in their talons. The Ministry of Defence is already pouring public money into developing so-called “biomimetic technology” , producing drones based on natural forms, apparently for the purposes of intelligence gathering in urban environments. At the same time, the UK is hoping to capitalise on the economic and environmental benefits that could in future be reaped by having companies use drones to make deliveries.

text: There have been many terrible events in the history of Northern Ireland's <trigger id='trigger-0'>conflict</trigger>, but few have seared the collective consciousness of its people as <trigger id='trigger-12'>those</trigger> on Friday, 21 July 1972, a day that became known as Bloody Friday. You could hear people screaming, crying and moaning. Such was the scale of the <trigger id='trigger-13'>attack</trigger>, witnesses at the time remember seeing people running in all directions, not knowing where the <role id='role-14-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='14'>bombs</role> were being <trigger id='trigger-14'>detonated</trigger>. As one report at the time described the scene,"it was impossible for anyone to feel perfectly safe". Car bombs While the scale of the <trigger id='trigger-10'>attack</trigger> was huge, it was two car <role id='role-10-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='10'>bombs</role> that between them <trigger id='trigger-11'>claimed</trigger> the <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>nine lives</role>-one at the Oxford Street bus station in the city centre, the other outside shops in <role id='role-11-Place'trigno='11'>Cavehill Road</role> in north Belfast. At <role id='role-9-Place'trigno='9'>Oxford St</role>, the busiest bus station in Northern Ireland, four Ulsterbus <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>workers</role> and two soldiers were <trigger id='trigger-9'>killed</trigger>. At the Cavehill Road <trigger id='trigger-18'>bomb</trigger>, the <role id='role-18-Victim'trigno='18'>victims</role> were two women and a 14-year-old schoolboy. Of the <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>130</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>injured</trigger>, 77 were women or children out shopping in the city centre. One police officer at the scene <trigger id='trigger-19'>recalled</trigger> the events for the <role id='role-19-Participant'trigno='19'><role id='role-19-Participant'trigno='19'>BBC</role></role> series Provos in 1997."You could hear people screaming, crying and moaning. Collapsed ceasefire In terms of furthering its cause among nationalists, the <role id='role-21-Attacker'trigno='21'>IRA</role>'s decision to carry out the Bloody Friday <trigger id='trigger-21'>attacks</trigger> proved to be a disaster. Earlier in the year, the IRA had experienced a massive propaganda and recruitment boost after the <role id='role-8-Killer'trigno='8'>Parachute Regiment</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>killed</trigger> 13 <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>protesters</role> during Bloody Sunday in <role id='role-8-Place'trigno='8'>Derry</role>. Many joined believing that they had no other way to defend their communities. It required only one man with a loud hailer to clear each target area in no time. Former IRA leader Sean MacStiofain By June, the <role id='role-23-Participant'trigno='23'><role id='role-23-Participant'trigno='23'><role id='role-22-Communicator'trigno='22'>organisation</role></role></role> felt confident enough to <trigger id='trigger-22'>call</trigger> a ceasefire and <trigger id='trigger-23'>hold</trigger> secret talks with British ministers in <role id='role-23-Place'trigno='23'>London</role>. It remains the bloodiest year of the <trigger id='trigger-31'>conflict</trigger> in Northern Ireland. text: An unknown <trigger id='trigger-0'>virus</trigger> may be spreading within Venezuela's Aragua <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>state</role>, medical officials report; however, the state's governor denies these allegations and accuses the official of lying. According to the Venezuelan newspaper El Nacional, the crisis arose in Central Hospital of Maracay where personnel were seen with mouth covers. Social media began rumors about various deaths within the <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>hospital</role> caused by <trigger id='trigger-1'>bacteria</trigger> similar to Neisseria meningitides. Angel Sarmiento, president of Aragua Medical School, announced eight <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>people</role> died of the yet unidentified <trigger id='trigger-2'>disease</trigger>. He said it was not Ebola, meningitis, dengue or chikungunya. He added that the victims were four children and four adults. The symptoms exhibited by the dead were spots on the body that turned to boils, high fever, massive hemorrhaging stemming from smaller hemorrhagic incidents, and multi-organ failure. The disease took around 72 hours to run its course."We don't know what we are confronting,"Sarmiento said."We don't know if it's a virus or bacteria. How can we heal what we don't know?"However, there may not be any disease to battle. The governor of Aragua, who is also the state's leader of the United Socialist Party of Venezuela, denies Sarmiento's claims, according to the Latin American Herald Tribune. Gov. Tarek el Aissami said,"I need to start by categorically denying the existence of some <trigger id='trigger-3'>virus</trigger> or <trigger id='trigger-4'>bacteria</trigger> on the premises of <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'><role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>the Maracay Central Hospital</role></role> that is putting the lives of <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'><role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>patients</role></role> at risk."Aragua's governor refuted Sarmiento's claim and called them a"terrorist matrix that has a basic purpose, which is to create alarm, anguish in Aragua's population."He added that the deceased died of different causes, including an old man dying of diabetes and one of the children from leukemia."What you are is a criminal, who, irresponsibly using your status as a doctor, launched this campaign without finding out the facts, without investigating, and in these last few hours you've caused terrible anguish among the people of Aragua,"el Aissami said about Sarmiento. The governor called on the Attorney General's office to investigate Sarmiento.

text: The <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Cafetería Rolando</role> bombing was an <trigger id='trigger-0'>attack</trigger> on 13 September 1974 at the <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>Rolando cafe</role> in Calle del Correo, Madrid, Spain which <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> 13 <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-2'>wounded</trigger> <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>71</role>. Though no claim of responsibility was made, the attack is widely believed to have been <trigger id='trigger-23'>carried out</trigger> by the armed Basque separatist group <role id='role-23-Attacker'trigno='23'>ETA</role>. == Background == The Rolando Cafe was located on 4 Calle del Correo in Madrid, close to the General Directorate of Security, the headquarters of the Spanish Police. It was regularly frequented by members of the police force and security services. == The attack == The <role id='role-24-Artifact'trigno='24'><role id='role-3-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='3'>bomb</role></role> was <trigger id='trigger-24'>placed</trigger> at the entrance to the <role id='role-24-Place'trigno='24'><role id='role-3-Target'trigno='3'>building</role></role> and <trigger id='trigger-3'>exploded</trigger> on a Friday afternoon, during a busy lunchtime period. More than 300 people were eating in the neighbouring <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>El Tobogan restaurant</role> at the time of the <trigger id='trigger-4'>explosion</trigger>, two of <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>whom</role> were among the <trigger id='trigger-5'>dead</trigger>. The explosion caused significant <trigger id='trigger-6'>damage</trigger> to nearby <role id='role-6-Artifact'trigno='6'>buildings</role>, <trigger id='trigger-7'>shattering</trigger> the <role id='role-7-Artifact'trigno='7'>windows</role> of the nearby General Directorate of Security, while two <role id='role-8-Artifact'trigno='8'>cars</role> parked nearby were totally <trigger id='trigger-8'>destroyed</trigger>. The <role id='role-9-Instrument'trigno='9'>bomb</role> caused part of the Rolando Cafe's <role id='role-9-Artifact'trigno='9'>ceiling</role> to <trigger id='trigger-9'>collapse</trigger> and <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>guests</role> staying in a pension above were <trigger id='trigger-10'>injured</trigger> due to falling through the gaps in the ceiling. The police immediately arrived and cordoned off the scene. Two of the <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>12</role> initially <trigger id='trigger-11'>killed</trigger> and <role id='role-12-Victim'trigno='12'>11</role> of the <trigger id='trigger-12'>injured</trigger> were members of the police force. However the <trigger id='trigger-13'>wounded</trigger> included the number two of the Spanish Political Police, with the remainder employees and <role id='role-13-Victim'trigno='13'>customers</role> of the cafe. A thirteenth <role id='role-14-Victim'trigno='14'>victim</role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>died</trigger> in 1977 of <trigger id='trigger-18'>injuries</trigger> suffered during the attack. == Responses and arrests == The <role id='role-25-Communicator'trigno='25'>leadership</role> of ETA was taken aback by the responses to the attack and on 15 September, <trigger id='trigger-25'>issued</trigger> a <role id='role-25-Topic'trigno='25'>statement</role> denying their responsibility, though implicitly defending the bombing, claiming that the cafe was full of police agents. This caused tensions within the group, with some members believing that the <role id='role-15-Attacker'trigno='15'>organisation</role> had to admit responsibility for <trigger id='trigger-15'>attacks</trigger> carried out, even if the results were not those intended. The bombing gave those opposed to further liberalisation of the country, such as Blas Piñar, the opportunity to <trigger id='trigger-19'>attack</trigger> the Prime Minister <role id='role-19-Target'trigno='19'>Carlos Arias Navarro</role>. In the immediate period of confusion following the attack, some blamed the <trigger id='trigger-20'>attack</trigger> on the far-right. The police, however, concluded that ETA were responsible and launched an operation against the group's infrastructure in Madrid. Initially the police also blamed the Communist Party of Spain (PCE) of cooperating in the attack, but the PCE energetically denied involvement. Reports that police officers had received a circular advising them not to go to the Rolando Cafe or stand outside the building added to the mystery surrounding the incident. Leftists known to be sympathetic to ETA were <trigger id='trigger-16'>arrested</trigger>, including Eva Forest, wife of the communist playwright Alfonso Sastre, Mari Luz Fernandez and her relatives, Lidia Falcón, the theatre director Vicente Sainz de la Peña, construction worker Antonio Durán, pilot Bernardo Badell and his wife María del Carmen Nadal, the actress María Paz Ballesteros, and the writer <role id='role-16-Detainee'trigno='16'>Eliseo Bayo</role>. Between June 1975 and February 1976, courts dismissed the cases and released the defendants. However Eva Forest and Mari Luz Fernandez remained in prison as <role id='role-17-Defendant'trigno='17'>they</role> were <trigger id='trigger-17'>charged</trigger> with complicity in the <trigger id='trigger-21'>assassination</trigger> of <role id='role-21-Target'trigno='21'>Luis Carrero Blanco</role> one year before. However, neither Forest nor Luz Fernandez were tried for the Rolando bombing, as <role id='role-22-Defendant'trigno='22'>they</role> were <trigger id='trigger-22'>released</trigger> in June 1977 as part of a general amnesty for political prisoners. In 1981 Lidia Falcón published a denunciation of Eva Forest which suggested that Forest's role in the Rolando attack had been considerable. The government also offered a reward of one million pesetas for information leading to the capture of Juan Manuel Galarraga Mendizabal who they suspected of being a high ranking ETA figure involved in the bombing.
